title: JPEG vs RAW — The Key Differences

questions.question: What's the main difference between RAW and JPEG?
options: RAW is a video format; JPEG is a photo format
RAW is already edited; JPEG is unprocessed
RAW is minimally processed sensor data; JPEG is processed and compressed in-camera
RAW has fewer colors than JPEG
questions.reviewHint: RAW = more data, less processing; JPEG = processed & compressed.

questions.question: Which file is usually smaller straight out of the camera?
questions.reviewHint: JPEG compresses, so file sizes are smaller.

questions.question: You shot under tungsten light with the wrong white balance. Which file lets you fix WB most easily after the shot?
questions.reviewHint: RAW keeps full WB flexibility; JPEG bakes WB.

questions.question: To recover highlights/shadows and handle high contrast scenes, which gives you the most dynamic range?
questions.reviewHint: RAW usually stores more highlight/shadow detail.

questions.question: You need images ready to share quickly with pleasing contrast and sharpening without editing. Best choice?
questions.reviewHint: JPEG has in-camera processing (contrast, color, sharpening).

questions.question: Which settings are baked into JPEG but not into the underlying RAW data (only noted as metadata)?
questions.reviewHint: Style settings affect JPEG rendering, RAW keeps data for later edits.

questions.question: For long bursts (sports/wildlife), which typically maintains buffer longer at the same quality level?
questions.reviewHint: Smaller JPEG files = longer bursts before buffer fills.

questions.question: Typical bit depth comparison out of camera:
questions.reviewHint: RAW usually has higher bit depth → more tonal precision.

questions.question: You're shooting a difficult, high-contrast sunset and plan to edit later. Best choice?
questions.reviewHint: Use RAW for maximum recovery latitude.

questions.question: You must shoot and deliver quickly at an event with minimal editing. Best choice?
You want both flexibility for editing and a ready-to-share file from the same shot. What should you set?
questions.reviewHint: RAW+JPEG gives an editable RAW plus an instant JPEG.

questions.question: Which statement about noise reduction and sharpening is most accurate?
options: RAW files are always noisier in the final image
JPEG has in-camera NR/sharpening baked in; RAW leaves you to adjust these in editing
questions.reviewHint: JPEG bakes NR/sharpening; RAW offers control in post.
